So today, we're going to
finish this whirlwind tour

through problems. Different types of problems
and formulations and things

like that, and some
named problem classes. So last time I think we
quit right around here

on quasiconvex optimization. So that's when you minimize
a quasiconvex objective.

And here, you have to be-- I mean, you should be a little
bit worried because, in fact,

the basic-- probably the most important
fact about convex problems is that you can have
a local minimum--

you can't have a local minimum
that's not a global minimum. But for quasiconvex
optimization, that's false.

You can have that. So you have to be a
little bit more careful. Not that much careful, it's
not that hard to solve.

So the way you do this is if
a function is quasiconvex,

it means its sublevel
sets are convex. And so what we
introduce is a function

whose zero sublevel set
is the key sublevel set of your function.

And so this function
has to be convex. So if-- and how you
construct phi t,

there is completely generic
constructions of it. They're not useful, but
when people ask you,

how do you come up with that
phi t, you can always do it. Often it just is
suggested by the problem.

We looked at an example
last time that was this. I mean, here's an
interesting one. It's the ratio of a non-negative
over a positive function.

The numerator is convex and
the denominator is concave. So this function here, it
is definitely not convex,

necessarily, but
it is quasiconvex. And to check that,
what you do is you look

at the sublevel set of this. A p-- when is it true that
p of x divided by q of x is less than or equal to t?

If t is negative,
then this is simple because then the sublevel set
is empty and that's convex,

so that's cool,
so we really only have to worry about t positive. So if t is positive, then p of
x over q of x is less than t.

Well, this is true
without the t positive. That's true if and only if p
of x minus tq of x is less than

or equal to 0. Now the critical part. This is a convex function of
x, provided t is positive.

That's because q is concave. So you're just using one
of these simple rules

in your head. That's concave, multiplied by t
positive, still concave, minus, now it's convex,
and then it's a sum.

So this is the example. And what this allows you
to do is really cool.

It says that if I
wanted to check, does there exist an x for
which f0 of x is less than t?

I can check it by solving a
convex feasibility problem. So that's the idea here,
which is really cool.

And then, of course,
what you could do is you can just do bisection. You just say, well, can
you find an x where f0 of x

is less than 1.5? And if the answer is
yes, then you go cool. And by the way, you now
have a feasible point

with an objective
value of 1.5 or better. Then you'd say, all right,
how about 1 or how about 0.5

or how about minus 1? This kind of thing. So-- I mean, not minus 1
in this case, but still.

So anyway, that's
just bisection, and that actually works.

So the algorithm is
actually just what I said. I start with an upper and a
lower bound on the optimal

value of the objective. I just query-- I ask-- what I do is I take the
midpoint of that interval and I

ask, is there a is there a-- I solve a convex
feasibility problem

to find out if these
inequalities hold. If they do, then that tells
you that p star is less than

or equal to that value. It means you're
above-- and by the way, now I update my upper
bound, I pull it

down to this halfway mark. If it goes the other way
around, I take my lower bound and I pull it up to
the halfway mark.

And what this tells
you is that your-- let's see, your interval of
ignorance about the optimal

value, that's-- p star
is in some interval, that interval shrinks by a
factor of 2 every iteration.

Or if you like, you
could even say this. You could say that you
obtain one bit of information

in about p star
every time you solve one of these convex
feasibility problems.

And by one bit, I mean that
it's-- you actually reduce your uncertainty exactly
by a factor of 2.

So that's it. And this is standard
and it works and so on. So that's quasiconvex
optimization.
